data.value: This is a generalization of a histogram2d function.  A histogram divides the space into bins, and returns the count of the number of points in each bin.  This function allows the computation of the sum, mean, median, or other statistic of the values (or set of values) within each bin.
Binedges: All but the last (righthand-most) bin is half-open.  In other words, if

an integer that represents the bin in which it belongs.  The representation depends on the

to its corresponding bin (using row-major ordering). Note that the returned linearized bin indices are used for an array with extra bins on the outer binedges to capture values outside of the defined bin bounds. If 'True': The returned
is a shape (2,N) ndarray where each row indicates bin placements for each dimension respectively.  In each dimension, a binnumber of
means the corresponding value is between (D_edge[i-1], D_edge[i]), where 'D' is either 'x' or 'y'.
A sequence of values to be binned along the first dimension.
A sequence of values to be binned along the second dimension.
The data on which the statistic will be computed.  This must be the same shape as
, or a list of sequences - each with the same shape as
is such a list, the statistic will be computed on each independently.
The statistic to compute (default is 'mean'). The following statistics are available:
the number of bins for the two dimensions (nx = ny = bins),
the number of bins in each dimension (nx, ny = bins),
the bin edges for the two dimensions (x_edge = y_edge = bins),
the bin edges in each dimension (x_edge, y_edge = bins).
If the bin edges are specified, the number of bins will be, (nx = len(x_edge)-1, ny = len(y_edge)-1).

children.type_: int or [int, int] or array_like or [array, array], optional

data.value: The leftmost and rightmost edges of the bins along each dimension (if not specified explicitly in the
parameters): [[xmin, xmax], [ymin, ymax]]. All values outside of this range will be considered outliers and not tallied in the histogram.
